channel.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
channel.description: Hi all, just got my new Axoloti, as topic, has anyone tried anyway to do so? thanks.

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @Sebo Sebastian Cordoves
item.description:
@Sebo wrote:

Check my post here:

Axoloti as a 5U Module Hardware
Hi all: I did a module with Axoloti for my 5U modular. The module have: 4 CV inputs (CV control + CV Atenautor) connected to PA0 to PA3. 1 Digital Input (with voltaje protection) connected to PB0. 2 CV outputs (0 to 10V) connected to PA4 and PA5 DAC outputs. 2 CV outputs (0 to 10V) connected to PA6 and PA7 using PWM at 10KHz. 6 Digital outputs connected to PC0 to PC5. 1 LED connected to PB1. [image] [image] Notes: I used MCP6002 (not MCP602), just didn't have a library for the MCP6002 in E…

Read full topic

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @dusjagr Marc Dusseiller
item.description:
@dusjagr wrote:

we are working on it....
a lot of digital talk her. but we need to go into the analog world now.
adding a capacitor will already lead to a symetric sygnal and we then amplify it to our range we want to.
maybe some decent filtering stage would be useful.
more to come soon...
m

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @shihweichieh
item.description:
@shihweichieh wrote:

Hi Ott, thanks for the reply, can you screenshot the way you refer to make a constant value? I am not sure if I get it.

and if you say I can only adjust it between -64 to 63, does that mean I can't generate a 0.00001hz sin wave or a constant value to PA4?

Read full topic
item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @Ott
item.description:
@Ott wrote:

IIRC the patcher objects work at -64 to 63 when the total range is -128 to 127 so you can add oscilators together without clipping. Try sending the output through both inputs of math/+.

Read full topic

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @shihweichieh
item.description:
@shihweichieh wrote:

thanks for the answer, then which object in Axoloti to make a constant +/- 3.3V audio output like [sig~] object in max? I only get 1.6-1.7 readings from PA4 and PA5, is that correct? and I need negative voltage too....

item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @lis0r
item.description:
@lis0r wrote:

As long as you add an appropriately designed reconstruction filter, the PWM outputs will be an analogue. Their steppiness depends on their bit depth, but that's a problem on all DACs.

Read full topic

item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @JonasBers Jonas Bers
item.description:
@JonasBers wrote:

on the off chance that your laser is TTL, the 3.3v digital outputs would work fine for RGB, then you could scale the analog outputs to 5v for x and y. I have a TTL laser and that's how I'm planning to implement.

Read full topic
item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @jfcharles Jean-Francois Charles
item.description:
@jfcharles wrote:

PWM gives you a square wave, with an adjustable duty cycle. With an Arduino Uno, it's the only way to get a "kind-of-analog" output, it looks like this:
http://www.arduino.cc/en/Tutorial/PWM
With axoloti, the "on" value is 3.3V (not 5V), and the PWM frequency is currently fixed at 97.65Hz.
You could filter the PWM output to try to get "only" the DC component, i.e. the average value, using additional electronic circuitry.

Read full topic
item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @shihweichieh
item.description:
@shihweichieh wrote:

Thanks Charles, I expected analog DC coupling outputs, the sample rates affects my laser graphic quality. (by my understanding PWM gives you ladder shape wave form according to sample rate?)

but I guess I have to accept only two outputs now...

Read full topic
item.source: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @jfcharles Jean-Francois Charles
item.description:
@jfcharles wrote:

It depends how "analog" you want them to be. I guess that PWM would work, in which case you can have more than 10 outputs giving you continuous values from 0 to 3.3 V. You'll need to filter the PWM signal so that it fits your downstream application.
Check the GPIO outputs there:

Official pin out/ports documentation

here is my nonofficial gpio I/O port overview. edited 31.12.2015 [image] Download

Read full topic

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?
item.dc:creator: @shihweichieh
item.description:
@shihweichieh wrote:

Thanks but at least I need 5 analog outputs with 3.3V, I only see 2 in the patch? (PA4, PA5)

I wanna use it for my laser CV control, i send analog signals directory to my galvanometers, the sample rate is related to the laser graphic resolution.

but still so excited to have my first board!

item.title: Is is possible to have analog outputs (+/-5V)?

item.description:

In its current basic form and firmware etc, no. But I guess it depends on what you are trying to do ? It has PWM's, you can interface with other microcontrollers etc..
